abstracts.cdata!:
The project rating is satisfactory,
            particularly in respect to human resources development,
            since new approaches to the management of protected areas in
            the Ukraine were established, and, proactive habitat
            management measures prescribed, within European conservation
            initiatives. Furthermore, the project was instrumental in
            improving the protection, and management of the
            bio-diversity of the Danube Biosphere Reserve. Regardless of
            success, the lessons suggest, in the first place, that
            public education, and awareness activities, should
            adequately be planned well in advance of project
            implementation, to allow a meaningful public involvement to
            take place. This could have been initiated through
            awareness, and education activities, developed through
            non-governmental organizations, and/or small grants
            programs. Secondly, the creation of a biosphere reserve
            should be implemented in phases, in order to provide the
            administration, and local communities, with the
            understanding to adequately plan for financial, and
            managerial responsibilities. Furthermore, if the
            administration of protected areas is to work effectively
            with local communities, it is suggested that technical
            studies be used as a guide in the use of reserve resources,
            and, should be undertaken at the early stages of the project.
